bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to [s.n.] Tillery, October 15, 1914

div1.p: [Carter] reports on his observations of mosquito breeding conditions. He recommends mosquito control measures for a pond and inquires about when he will need to appear in court.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to [s.n.] Tillery, October 15, 1914
div1.p:
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.
Oct. 15, 1914. Dear Mr. Tillery:

In addition to my field notes, of which Mr. Cordell took a
copy, the following general observations on my recent trip should be
submitted, I suppose to him.

(1) The lateness of the season--especially as we had a fair-
ly cold September--would make against the breeding of Anopheles mos-
quitoes and less of them would be found than if the survey had been
made earlier. This effect--low temperature--would be more marked at
shady breeding places than in those exposed to the sun and in fact in
pools orand marshes in good shade we did not find young larvae (“wiggle-
tails”)--although some old ones and shells were found in such places
shewing that Anopheles had been breeding in such places, but were not
breeding then. I restrict this statement to “pools and marshes” be-
cause where a stream ran from a breeding place exposed to the sun in-
to the shade some young larvae would frequently be found in the shade
--washed down from above where they were breeding.

Hence the breeding which was found was less than that which
existed during the summer months, especially in shady places.

(2) My survey began Oct. 5th., just after a considerable rain
on the 3th. and 4th. This washed out many of the small streams in
the pools of which larvae were breeding. They were found in such
streams only in places behind little hammocks etc. where they had
lodged and in side pools and naturally in smaller number than would
have been the case before the rain. In some places the stream was
absolutely scoured out and if it had contained any larvae before the
-2-
rain none would have been left: My search thus was of necessity
almost confined to pools and marshes about the heads of streams
which had not been washed out, or at least less washed out than the
streams lower down.

This rain was repeated when the other physicians came down
and was evidently quite hard the night of Monday, Oct. 12th. and
the conditions for demonstrating larvae in streams were very un-
favorable next morning.

(3) After the rise of the pond fish appeared in Smith's
Creek, as high as Forest Road any way, and no larvae were then
found in it below that road. Previously quite annumber of larvae
had been found in it--Oct. 10th. with Rankin: and Oct 7th.: On
the 7th. no fish were seen up in the creek: On the 10th. there
were some and on the 12th. they were quite abundant and no larvae
in creek below Forest Road, although they were in side pools.
Up the creek further, from the crossing going to Mr. Meacham's up
to well above the old mill site on Mr. Henry's land, they were abun-
dant on Oct. 8th.: And at the former place--the only place in this
section we tried--on Oct. 13th. in spite of a freshet in the creek.
There were few or no fsish seen in this creek during the September
inspection and many larvae in both the creek and side pools as far
up as a mile above Fork Road (left fork.)

(4) Much stress should be laid on the presence or absence of
men or animals near a place physically suited for breeding. Since the
female Anopheles requires a meal of blood to enable her to lay her
eggs, obviously the presence or absence of a convenient blood supply
will make much difference in the number of mosquitoes produced in
places otherwise equally suited for breeding.

Such places then, adjacent to houses: pastures etc. which
have been abandoned, will now be breeding less, possibly much less,
than they were when the premises were occupied.

As all of the above conditions militate against the breeding
of Anopheles it is obvious that a decidedly larger number would
have been found at the places examined had the examination been
made in the hot summer and especially in the neighborhood of pre-
mises now abandoned had the examination been made when they were
occupied.

About the only thing I can suggest--which is feasible--to
lessen the danger of the pond doing damage is to cut down the
small sweet gums and willows--the former especially--which grow
just in the water near the edge. These do not die on account of
their roots being covered by water. This cannot be done until
the low water next fall, because they must be cut as low as pos-
sible so that the tops may be covered by water when they sprout.
I do not think it would be a big job as few of them will require
more than one stroke of an axe. They keep the drift from reach-
ing the bank and the drift sometimes shelters mosquito larvae.

I expect to have to go to the meeting of the Southern
Medical Association at Richmond--Nov. 9th. to 12th.--and if I
am wanted to apprar at court I hope it will not cover these days.
Please advise me at what time it will be necessary for me to be
at court--Waynesboro I presume.
